title: Prefigurative Community Building (Part 23): Childcare and Elder Care Collectives as Power With Coordination Patterns
summary: Reclaim care as shared community responsibility through horizontal childcare and elder care collectives that reject atomization and commodification.

Community.summary: Build reciprocal care systems that support children, elders, and caregivers through collective responsibility.

level0: Start conversations with other parents/caregivers about mutual support
Organize informal childcare swaps with trusted neighbors
Share meals across generations in your community
level1: Form a care pod of 4-10 households for regular support
Create care calendars and resource sharing systems
Develop collective agreements around safety and inclusion
level2: Establish rotating coordination roles to prevent hierarchy
Hold regular reflection circles to adjust care rhythms
Connect with other care collectives for knowledge sharing
level3: Support formation of additional autonomous care pods
Advocate for policy changes supporting collective care models
Build lasting infrastructure for community-controlled care

Knowledge.summary: Develop and share knowledge about cooperative caregiving and intergenerational support.

level0: Learn about cooperative care models vs nuclear family isolation
Study successful care collectives like Kairos Fellowship
level1: Practice participatory mapping of community care skills and needs
Document your care collective's agreements and processes
level2: Host workshops on forming care collectives
Create resources about rotating care responsibilities
level3: Develop comprehensive guides for cooperative care organizing
Research and document impacts of collective vs individual care

Narrative.summary: Challenge narratives of individualized care and promote stories of collective responsibility.

level0: Share stories about the benefits of collective caregiving
Challenge myths about nuclear family being 'natural' or optimal
level1: Advocate for community-centered rather than institution-centered care
Write and share experiences of cooperative care practices
level2: Lead community discussions about reimagining care as shared responsibility
Create media highlighting successful intergenerational care models
level3: Contribute to cultural shift toward viewing collective care as normal
Mentor others in articulating visions of community-controlled care
